comments.body: fwiw you can statically cross compile cgo from linux to all other arches, it's not something I am proud of knowing how to do though

Thanks for pointing at a doc flaw.
That's exactly what my the intention is with this section, to describe how to cross-compile statically with CGO code for another architecture.

However, I see that here it says `compilation` in the header, when it should be `cross-compilation`, and likewise in other places. Will fix.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +465,469 @@This is especially useful if we want to include the binary in a container.
If the binary is statically compiled, we may use `busybox` or even `scratch` as the base image.
This should be the preferred way of compiling binaries that strictly require C code to be a part of it.

#### GOARM

comments.body: If your go installation is owned by root then this will fail.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +319,323 @@```console
# From build/build-image/cross/Dockerfile when we're using Go 1.5+
$ for platform in ${PLATFORMS}; do GOOS=${platform%/*} GOARCH=${platform##*/} go install std; done
```

comments.body:
Again, if we had CI that built and ran on all supported architectures, I will feel more comfortable.
I feel less comfortable claiming support on an arch without sufficient testing.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +227,231 @@In fact, we faced this problem while this proposal was being written; in [#25243](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/25243). It is quite obvious that the release blocker is of higher priority.

However, before temporarily [deactivating builds](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/commit/2c9b83f291e3e506acc3c08cd10652c255f86f79), the author of the breaking PR should first try to fix the problem. If it turns out being really hard to solve, builds for the affected platform may be deactivated and a P1 issue should be made to activate them again.

## Cross-compilation details (for reference)
